JUDGES: Isabelle Berro-Lefèvre;Karel Jungwiert;Mark Villiger;Peer Lorenzen;Rait Maruste;Renate Jaeger;Zdravka Kalaydjieva
TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in PERSON . He was represented before the ORG by Mr A. Kazakov , a lawyer practising in ORG . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , PERSON , of ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

On DATE the applicant was conscripted into the NORP armed forces to complete his military service . He was physically fit at the time . The applicant served primarily with ORG and was stationed in several garrisons .
On DATE he was transferred to garrison no . CARDINAL in the town of GPE to attend a radiotelegraph training course .
A medical examination of DATE pronounced the applicant physically fit .
According to the applicant his platoon commander in GPE , Lieutenant A. , started to systematically ill - treat him because he failed to meet the performance standards required of him .
The applicant visited the garrison ’s infirmary on DATE . He was diagnosed with “ neurosis ” and prescribed antidepressants .

TIME in DATE the applicant was ordered to the office of the platoon officers . PERSON , Senior PERSON and PERSON were present . According to the applicant , they criticised him for his low performance in the training course and , as punishment , ordered him to do QUANTITY . When he got down and started the pushups , PERSON and Senior PERSON started to kick him with their military boots . He was allegedly kicked numerous times in the head , neck and stomach . PERSON allegedly witnessed the beating . The officers then warned the applicant not to tell anyone what had happened .
According to the applicant , soon after that he started having problems with his vision and had pain in his neck .

On an unspecified date the applicant visited the garrison ’s infirmary . It is unclear whether any injuries were found on his person . The garrison doctor apparently diagnosed the applicant with cervical spondylosis and redirected him to ORG for an X - ray examination .
On DATE the applicant was examined in ORG where the diagnosis of cervical spondylosis was confirmed .

The applicant visited the garrison ’s infirmary on CARDINAL and CARDINAL May and again on DATE when he was diagnosed with “ neurosis ” . He was redirected to ORG where he was hospitalised for an undetermined DATE . Upon his discharge from the hospital he was given home leave on medical grounds .
Upon expiration of the home leave , on DATE the applicant returned to his former garrison in the village of ORG .

The applicant continued to seek medical treatment . He visited the garrison ’s infirmary in ORG on DATE and DATE and CARDINAL and DATE . On each occasion he was diagnosed with “ neurosis ” and was prescribed antidepressants .
After a medical examination on DATE the applicant was pronounced physically fit .

On DATE the applicant suffered his first seizure involving convulsion of the limbs , frothing at the mouth and loss of consciousness . The applicant was taken to ORG where he was hospitalised from DATE to DATE . He suffered a second seizure while in hospital and was diagnosed with “ suspected epilepsy ” . Upon being discharged from the hospital the applicant was given home leave on medical grounds .
While on home leave he suffered a third seizure on DATE .

After returning to his garrison , the applicant had a follow - up examination at ORG on DATE . He was apparently redirected to ORG of ORG in GPE ( “ MMA ” ) , where he was hospitalised from DATE . The applicant was diagnosed with :
“ PERSON dystonia . Syncope . [ Observed ] pro - epilepsy ” .
On DATE the applicant was discharged from the military as the term of his military service had expired .
On an unspecified later date he was pronounced unfit for active military service on medical grounds and was removed from the military ’s reserve list .
Following the applicant ’s discharge from the military his medical condition continued to deteriorate and the number and frequency of the seizures increased .
Following a fourth seizure on DATE the applicant was hospitalised at the ORG from DATE to CARDINAL DATE . He was diagnosed with :
“ Epilepsy – acute seizures . Lymphadenitis generalised non - specific ” .
On DATE a CAT scan was performed on the applicant ’s head at ORG . It was discovered that he had a cerebral oedema .
The applicant was again hospitalised at ORG from DATE and then from DATE to CARDINAL DATE . During his first stay he was diagnosed with :
“ Head contusion . Symptomatic [ of epilepsy ] . ”
During his second stay the diagnosis was :
“ [ Epilepsy ] – acute seizures . Massive functional cumulation . ”

DATE and DATE the applicant was hospitalised at the ORG . On DATE he underwent an operation during which a cavernous angioma ( a benign vascular malformation which can be caused by a trauma to the spinal cord ) was removed from his brain .

On an unspecified date in DATE the applicant ’s mother complained to ORG ( the “ ORG ” ) of the deterioration in her son ’s health while he was in the military . In response , by letter of DATE , the ORG informed her that her son had received all the medical assistance required .

In DATE , at the applicant ’s request , a doctor drew up an expert report on his state of health . On the basis of the relevant medical documents and the applicant ’s explanations , he concluded that the applicant had developed epilepsy during the time of his military service but that it could not be established with certainty whether its cause had been related to the alleged beating of the applicant in DATE .
On DATE the applicant himself complained to ORG . He apparently named the officers involved in the alleged beating in the NORP garrison and PERSON , who had allegedly witnessed it .

By order of DATE the Chairman of ORG set up an internal commission to investigate the applicant ’s accusations . In the course of its work , the commission questioned PERSON , Senior PERSON and the doctor at the NORP garrison ’s infirmary . PERSON was not sought out for questioning because he had left the military in DATE . The officers questioned denied that the applicant had been ill - treated or that they had beaten him . The garrison ’s doctor also denied that she had seen any injuries on the applicant during the medical examinations performed at the time .
By letter of DATE the ORG informed the applicant that the investigation had concluded that his accusations were unfounded and that his complaints would not be followed up any further .

On DATE the applicant also filed a complaint with the NORP military prosecutor ’s office , which opened a preliminary investigation and questioned Senior PERSON and the doctor at the NORP garrison , who both said that they did not remember the applicant . PERSON denied ever beating or hitting soldiers and the garrison doctor denied any knowledge of ill - treatment of the applicant . PERSON was not questioned as he had not been found at his known address .

On DATE a prosecutor from the NORP military prosecutor ’s office refused to open criminal proceedings in relation to the alleged illtreatment of the applicant . On the basis of the testimonies obtained , the applicant ’s medical records and the medical expert report drawn up in DATE , he concluded that it had not been established that the applicant had been beaten in the ORG garrison or that his medical condition had resulted from a trauma allegedly sustained during that beating .
On appeal by the applicant , on DATE that decision was upheld by the military appellate prosecutor ’s office in GPE .
It appears that the applicant did not appeal against that decision to ORG .

By decision of DATE , ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) assessed the applicant ’s medical condition and recognised him to be disabled with PERCENT disability . Upon appeal , by decisions of DATE and DATE , ORG ( “ the CLEMC ” ) quashed the decision of the ORG and assessed the applicant to be disabled with PERCENT disability . The starting date of the disability was determined to be DATE . In its decisions , the CLEMC referred to the applicant ’s allegations that he had been beaten in DATE but did not conclude that this had caused his medical condition .
In DATE the applicant started to receive an army pension .

His disability was reassessed by the ORG on DATE . The commission found that the number and frequency of his seizures had decreased and assessed the applicant to be disabled with PERCENT disability . Upon appeal , by decision of CARDINAL DATE , the ORG quashed the decision of the ORG and further decreased the applicant ’s percentage of disability to PERCENT . Once again the CLEMC referred to the applicant ’s alleged beating in DATE but did not state that it considered this to be the cause of his medical condition .
The applicant was entitled to appeal against the decision of the CLEMC but apparently failed to do so .
Apparently , as a result of the reduction of his disability level , on DATE the applicant ’s army pension was decreased from an unspecified amount to MONEY ( the equivalent of CARDINAL ) .
On DATE the applicant filed a complaint with the prosecutor ’s office , challenging the grounds for his discharge from the military on DATE .

By letter of DATE the NORP regional prosecutor ’s office informed him that it was not competent to rule on the matter and that instead he should initiate an administrative action challenging the order for his discharge . It does not appear that the applicant initiated any such action .

The applicant filed several more complaints to various authorities seeking compensation for the damage caused as a result of the illness he developed while in the military . In response , by letters of CARDINAL and DATE from ORG , letters of DATE and DATE from ORG and a letter of DATE from the ORG , he was informed of the procedure and formalities required to claim the special compensation provided for in section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW , in force at the time . In particular , the applicant was advised of the need to obtain an evaluation of his medical condition by ORG , which apparently he did not do .
Neither did he bring an action before the civil courts to seek compensation , as he was expressly entitled to do under section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW , in force at the time .
